message_1: What is the half-life of a radioactive material that started with 100 grams and decayed to 25 grams in 20 years? If the material has a decay constant of 0.01 per year, how much of the material will remain after 40 years?
message_2:
To find the half-life of the radioactive material, we can use the formula:

N(t) = N0 * (1/2)^(t/T)

where N(t) is the amount of the material remaining after time t, N0 is the initial amount of the material, T is the half-life, and t is the time elapsed.

In this case, we have:

25 grams = 100 grams * (1/2)^(20 years / T)

Divide both sides by 100 grams:

0.25 = (1/2)^(20 years / T)

Now, take the logarithm of both sides:

log(0.25) = (20 years / T) * log(1/2)

Solve for T:

T = (20 years * log(1/2)) / log(0.25)

T ≈ 10 years

So, the half-life of the radioactive material is approximately 10 years.

Now, to find the amount of the material remaining after 40 years, we can use the decay constant formula:

N(t) = N0 * e^(-λt)

where N(t) is the amount of the material remaining after time t, N0 is the initial amount of the material, λ is the decay constant, and t is the time elapsed.

In this case, we have:

N(40) = 100 grams * e^(-0.01 per year * 40 years)

N(40) ≈ 100 grams * e^(-0.4)

N(40) ≈ 100 grams * 0.67032

N(40) ≈ 67.03 grams

So, approximately 67.03 grams of the material will remain after 40 years.
